pullRequest.body:
The file Mathlib.GroupTheory.Perm.Cycle.Basic was too big and this PR splits it in several components:
* `Mathlib.GroupTheory.Perm.Cycle.Basic` contains everything related to a permutation being a cycle,
* `Mathlib.GroupTheory.Perm.Cycle.Factors` is about the cycles of a permutation and the decomposition of a permutation into disjoint cycles
* `Mathlib.GroupTheory.Perm.Closure` contains generation results for the permutation groups
* `Mathlib.GroupTheory.Perm.Finite` contains general results specific to permutation of finite types

I moved some results to `Mathlib.GroupTheory.Perm.Support`

I also moved some results from `Mathlib.GroupTheory.Perm.Sign` to `Mathlib.GroupTheory.Perm.Finite`

Some imports could be reduced, and the shake linter required a few adjustments in some other.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
> @YaelDillies I don't understand what is so terrible about this split. I think it is a clear improvement over the status quo, and you're of course free to improve further in the future.

I agree that it's an improvement. I propose to merge it unless there a specific reason against it (also it risks to rot).

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Should this be left commented out?
The file does not import Mathlib.GroupTheory.OrderOfElement anymore, so the example does not compile.
@AntoineChambert-Loir Do you think it makes sense to move it to a place where it does typecheck? If so, please mvoe it.
I believe it was here because it has something to do with testing whether a permutation is even or odd… but the file where docs#orderOf is defined seems to be a good place.
finally, I put it in Mathlib/GroupTheory/SpecificGroups/Alternating (otherwise, I needed to add an import…)
Please sort and remove the `--`

```suggestion
The main definition of this file is `Equiv.Perm.sign`, associating a `ℤˣ` sign with a
permutation.
```

I'm personally a fan of semantic linebreaks (https://sembr.org/).

We don't have a policy in mathlib concerning sembr or justifying text. I would leave this as it is.
(That's not the subject here, but I am used to 80 chars terminals, and I find these overflow to 100 chars very disturbing, I get many lines with few symbols, hence less information on my screen.)

```suggestion
import Mathlib.Data.Finset.NoncommProd
import Mathlib.Data.Int.ModEq
import Mathlib.GroupTheory.Perm.Cycle.Basic
import Mathlib.Logic.Equiv.Fintype
```

Sorry, this is unrelated to the split, but I've just noticed something is wrong with our generality
```suggestion

## TODO

Generalise `Equiv.Perm.cycleOf` to arbitrary types.
```

```suggestion
import Mathlib.Algebra.Module.BigOperators
```
I don't understand what will be the effect of this suggestion.
I am ordering alphabetically the imports

```suggestion
```
Idem.
What's going on here?
What do you mean?
Why did the namespace move inside the section? The namespace is supposed to be outside, with sections inside

Does closing a namespace close all introduction of variables?
It is not so clear in the documentation.
Apparently, it does not. These `section`had the intent of isolating variables introduced here and there.
I did however made the change.
and here
I made the change.
and here (why did these two lemmas move?)
Because I put all the `IsCycle`lemmas together, and then the `IsCycleOn`lemmas. Previously, everything was in an indefinite order.

I'm not sure "indefinite order" is very fair. Those lemmas were later because they talk about specific permutations rather than general ones.

If you really want to move those lemmas, you should keep the namespacing untouched and just add `_root_.Int` to their names
```suggestion

theorem _root_.Int.addLeft_one_isCycle : (Equiv.addLeft 1 : Perm ℤ).IsCycle :=
  ⟨0, one_ne_zero, fun n _ => ⟨n, by simp⟩⟩
#align int.add_left_one_is_cycle Int.addLeft_one_isCycle

theorem _root_.Int.addRight_one_isCycle : (Equiv.addRight 1 : Perm ℤ).IsCycle :=
  ⟨0, one_ne_zero, fun n _ => ⟨n, by simp⟩⟩
#align int.add_right_one_is_cycle Int.addRight_one_isCycle

section Conjugation
```
By “indefinite”, I meant that the small sections were alternating between stuff about IsCycle and IsCycleOn.  I just put all IsCycle lemmas in one place, and all IsCycleOn lemmas in another place.

You're adding an import?
No, it's already there but Github doesn't let me do suggestions over deleted lines.

```suggestion
```
Can you split off that split to its own PR? This one is getting out of hand
I would prefer not to.

Reverting the change to Sign would mean finding what to move and rechecking imports. The handful of lemmas I moved were about something else than Sign — just needed for that.
IIRC, some files that used `Sign` could stop using it.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion * `Equiv.Perm.cycleFactors`: `f.cycleFactors` is a list of disjoint cyclic permutations ```
